etymologies: late 16th century: from Latin reciprocat- ‘moved backwards and forwards’, from the verb reciprocare, from reciprocus (see reciprocal)

definitions: respond to (a gesture or action) by making a corresponding one

examples.text: perhaps I was expected to reciprocate with some remark of my own

shortDefinitions: respond to gesture or action by making corresponding one

definitions: experience the same (love, liking, or affection) for someone as that person does for oneself

examples.text: her passion for him was not reciprocated

shortDefinitions: feel affection or love for someone in same way that they feel it for oneself

definitions: (of a part of a machine) move backward and forward in a straight line

examples.text: when you're shooting most semiautomatic handguns, the slide reciprocates as part of the firing cycle

shortDefinitions: (of part of machine) move backwards and forwards in straight line
